item.title: Seoul Live Updates: As Nation Mourns, a Focus on How a Festive Night Turned Deadly
item.description: A crowd surge during a Halloween celebration in a nightlife district killed more than 150 people. Witnesses say police presence was scant, even though people were thronging the streets.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: A man bowed to the memorial for the victims of stempede in Itaewon, Seoul, on Oct. 30th, 2022, in Seoul, South Korea.

item.title: A Momentous Presidential Contest in Brazil Between Bolsonaro and Lula
item.description: Voters are choosing between two of the most influential political titans in the country’s modern history in a vote with major implications for Brazil and the world.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri para The New York Times

item.title: Russia’s Exit From Grain Deal Risks Worsening Food Crisis, West Says
item.description: The top E.U. diplomat accused Russia of threatening a key export route for food as the U.N. and Turkey pushed to revive a deal they helped broker.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A resident who survived seven months under Russian occupation, in a village in the Kherson region of Ukraine, on Saturday.

item.title: Gujarat, India: At Least 60 Killed After Bridge Collapses
item.description: The bridge, in the state of Gujarat, was reopened recently after renovation.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:credit: Rajesh Ambaliya/Associated Press
item.media:description: Rescuers in India worked at night after a suspension bridge in western Gujarat State collapsed on Sunday.

item.title: ‘Indescribable’: Somalis Recount Horror of Blasts that Killed at Least 100
item.description: Twin explosions were the deadliest terrorist attack in the country in five years and underscored the growing threat posed by the terrorist group Al Shabab.
item.dc:creator: Hussein Mohamed and Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Hassan Ali Elmi/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Destroyed buildings in Mogadishu, Somalia, on Sunday, a day after two explosions targeted the Ministry of Education.

item.title: Palestinian Voters Debate Staying Home for Israeli Election
item.description: As Israel prepares to go to the polls again, some of the voters who helped propel an Arab party into the governing coalition for the first time are worried about a lack of results.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Mahmoud Illean/Associated Press
item.media:description: An Israeli Arab voting in last year’s election. A million Palestinians are eligible to vote in Israel, 17 percent of the electorate.

item.title: Surfing in Britain? It’s Chilly but Brilliant and Widening in Appeal.
item.description: On the North Devon coast, where breathtaking cliffs give way to barreling waves, the surfing scene can hold its own among the best in Europe, and more girls and women are taking it on.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of Wave Wahines, a women and girls only surf club, taking part in an afternoon lesson this month on Croyde Beach in North Devon, England.

item.title: U.S. Releases Guantánamo’s Oldest Prisoner
item.description: Saifullah Paracha, 75, was accused of being a Qaeda sympathizer and was held for two decades. But he was never charged with a crime.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Courtesy of Clive Stafford Smith
item.media:description: Saifullah Paracha on Saturday at a McDonald’s in Karachi, Pakistan.

item.title: Did Germany Learn From Its Russia Trouble? The Test May Come in China.
item.description: On the eve of Chancellor Olaf Scholz’s first trip to Beijing, concerns are growing that economic dependence on China is leaving his country vulnerable — again.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold and Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Clemens Bilan/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: As Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany prepares for his first visit to Beijing on Thursday, the country’s intelligence chiefs and allies are warning him against pursuing business as usual with China.

item.title: At Least 45 Dead as Nalgae Makes Landfall in the Philippines
item.description: Severe Tropical Storm Nalgae made landfall early Saturday and was expected to continue bringing strong winds and torrential rain to large areas of the country through the weekend.
item.dc:creator: Jason Gutierrez and John Yoon
item.media:credit: Philippines Marines Battalion Landing Team 5, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The aftermath of a landslide, which was set off by the heavy rains of Nalgae, on Friday in the town of Parang in the Philippines.

item.title: Will One Tuscan Port Stall Italy’s Drive for Energy Independence?
item.description: The residents of tiny Piombino understand the need to replace Russian gas imports. They just want a huge regasification vessel anchored somewhere else.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:credit: Chiara Negrello for The New York Times
item.media:description: The site in Piombino, Italy, where a 1,000-foot ship is to dock to prepare liquefied natural gas for onshore use.

item.title: Bolsonaro vs. Lula: What to Know About Brazil’s Runoff Election
item.description: The vote comes after a long and ugly campaign that pits two major political figures against each other in race that has tested the country’s democracy.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: A voter in the first round of presidential elections this month in São Paulo.

item.title: Australians Come Home After Years in ISIS Detention Camp
item.description: Dozens more Australians, many of them children, are still being held in Syria, but there is hope that the government will soon sponsor more releases.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost and Livia Albeck-Ripka
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A scene at Al-Hol detention camp in Kurdish-controlled northern Syria in 2019. Around 55,000 people, mostly women and children, live there in difficult conditions.

item.title: Another Israeli Election Looms, and a Familiar Face Plans a Comeback
item.description: Ousted from the prime minister’s office 16 months ago, Benjamin Netanyahu, the leading candidate, is out to prove his political obituaries were premature.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Benjamin Netanyahu in his bulletproof vehicle this month during a campaign stop in Netivot, Israel.

item.title: How a Festive Night in Seoul Turned Deadly
item.description: There were few police officers around as a mass of revelers swelled. From within the crowd came calls to “push, push” and a big shove, according to witnesses. Then, they began to fall.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun, John Yoon, Paul Mozur, Victoria Kim, Lee Su-Hyun and Jin Yu Young
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial on Sunday for the victims of the crowd surge in the Itaewon district of Seoul, the South Korean capital.

item.title: For Many Disabled People, a Battle to Stay in Australia or New Zealand
item.description: The two countries are outliers in routinely rejecting potential migrants on the basis of medical needs, leaving families with one ill member to struggle in a legal limbo.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: David Dare Parker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shaffan Muhammad Ghulam at school in Willetton, Australia. He has a rare genetic condition that has made his family ineligible to remain in the country because of what his treatment would cost the health care system.

item.title: Brazil’s Runoff Faces ‘Spiritual Warfare’ for Evangelical Voters
item.description: Evangelical Christians make up 30 percent of the population and are a crucial voting bloc for President Jair Bolsonaro.
item.dc:creator: Flávia Milhorance
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Evangelical Christians praying during a service in São Paulo in 2021.

item.title: A Mother Mourns a Daughter Lost in the Seoul Crowd Surge
item.description: Park Ga-young was a 19-year-old university student from a small town in South Korea who dreamed of studying fashion design in Canada.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon

item.title: How Cannibalism Became a Top Issue in Brazil’s Election
item.description: An old claim by Brazil’s president that he would “eat an Indian” took mudslinging to a new level.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jair Bolsonaro, then a congressman, and his son, Flávio, who filmed an interview in 2016 in which Mr. Bolsonaro said he would “eat an Indian.”

item.title: Why Did So Many More Women Than Men Die in the Itaewon Halloween Disaster?
item.description: Evidence that women may face greater risks in crowd crushes is inconclusive, an expert said.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:credit: Anthony Wallace/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: There were several factors that could have led to higher fatalities in women.

item.title: Expedition Finds Cameras Left by Yukon Mountaineers in 1937
item.description: Some of the cameras, from a climbing expedition 85 years ago, still had film in them. Conservators are looking to see if any images can be recovered.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:credit: Leslie Hittmeier/Teton Gravity Research
item.media:description: Griffin Post at the site of the abandoned camera cache.

item.title: Downtown Comebacks
item.description: The pandemic tested and reshaped the hearts of American cities.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Downtown Chicago in August.

item.title: Halloween Is a Recent Arrival in South Korea, but a Tradition in Itaewon
item.description: As Seoul has grown more cosmopolitan, and an increasing number of South Koreans have lived abroad and returned, Halloween has become a more popular occasion.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Ed Jones/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Halloween revelers in Itaewon in 2018.

item.title: What to know about Brazil’s pivotal election.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Election officials carried out an audit of electronic voting machines at the Regional Electoral Court in São Paulo on Saturday.

item.title: Tensions Over Racism Rock Australian Netball
item.description: “It’s been one of the toughest few weeks of my life,” one player said.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Darren Pateman/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Donnell Wallam, center, arriving on court for warmup before the netball match between the Australian Diamonds and the England Roses in Newcastle, Australia, on Wednesday.

item.title: The Family of a Victim of the Seoul Crowd Surge Tried Her Phone for Hours
item.description: Shin Su-Bin, 25, was out celebrating Halloween with friends when her father saw reports of the deadly crush.
item.dc:creator: Lee Su-Hyun
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Hannam Community Center on Sunday. People have been going to the center to find out about their loved ones after the crowd surge in the Itaewon neighborhood of Seoul.

item.title: The Crowd Crush is Seoul Was Like a ‘Tsunami Wave’
item.description: A witness described the force of the crowd pushing him back and forth near the scene of the disaster.
item.dc:creator: Paul Mozur
item.media:credit: Kim Hong-Ji/Reuters
item.media:description: People after being rescued at the scene where scores of people were killed and dozens were injured in a crowd crush in Seoul.

item.title: Witnesses Recall a Terrifying Evening in Seoul as the Crowd Surged
item.description: With officials unsure of what caused the disaster, recollections from people who were there are helping to paint a fuller picture.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun, Victoria Kim, John Yoon, Paul Mozur and Matt Stevens
item.media:credit: Kim Hong-Ji/Reuters
item.media:description: The scene where many people died while celebrating Halloween in Seoul on Saturday night.

item.title: At Least 151 Killed in Halloween Crowd Surge in Seoul
item.description: As many as 100,000 people were celebrating in a popular nightlife district in the center of the South Korean capital.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun, Chang Che and John Yoon
item.media:credit: Jung Yeon-Je/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Medical workers early Sunday transporting a victim of the Halloween crush in the Itaewon district of Seoul.

item.title: Survivor of Seoul Halloween Crowd Surge Describes Chaotic Scene
item.description: One teenager and her friend were engulfed by the crowd but managed to crawl out, were pulled into a tavern by adults, then escaped by inching along alley walls.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Lee Jin-Man/Associated Press
item.media:description: Injured people are helped after deadly crowd surge on Saturday.

item.title: Russia Withdraws From Grain Deal After Drone Attack on Black Sea Fleet
item.description: The Russian move jeopardized a rare case of wartime coordination aimed at lowering global food prices and combating hunger.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Family members grieving on Saturday in Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital, for a Ukrainian marine killed in combat.

item.title: How the Grain Deal Between Ukraine and Russia Worked
item.description: The process required the collaboration of the two warring nations, along with Turkey and the United Nations.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Grain bins storing corn, wheat, sunflower and soybeans in Boryspil, Ukraine, in May.

item.title: Two Explosions Rock Busy Intersection in Mogadishu
item.description: The attack comes as the newly elected government battles terrorist activity with a series of new measures aimed at the terrorist group Al Shabab.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Abdihalim Bashir/Abdihalim Bashir Via Reuters
item.media:description: Smoke rose following a car bomb near Somalia’s education ministry in Mogadishu on Saturday.

item.title: With Western Weapons, Ukraine Is Turning the Tables in an Artillery War
item.description: In the southern Kherson region, Ukraine now has the advantage in range and precision guidance of artillery, rockets and drones, erasing what had been a critical Russian asset.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Finbarr O’Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A team of Ukrainian soldiers armed a drone with bombs on Friday during a mission that destroyed a Russian armored personnel carrier on the front lines in the country’s southern Kherson region.

item.title: In Russia, Memorial Forced to Downsize Tribute to Stalin Victims
item.description: Memorial typically conducts a marathon reading of the names, ages, professions and dates of death of those killed under Stalin, but it had to find other ways to honor the victims after the authorities banned it.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Nanna Heitmann
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times

item.title: Saudi Halloween: Once-Banned Holiday Now Haunted by Masked Monsters
item.description: Only a few years ago, a Halloween party meant arrest. Now, a government-sponsored “horror weekend” means sold-out costume shops and scary clowns. “Saudi is changing,” said a young man going as a wizard.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim and Tamir Kalifa
item.media:description: Mufleh al-Qahtani and Mubarak al-Qahtani in their car after buying Halloween costumes in Riyadh, the Saudi capital.

item.title: Garden Varieties
item.description: Fall is well and truly here. It’s a good time to check in with your houseplants.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: One in Five Canadians Is Now an Immigrant, and the Nation Approves
item.description: Even as immigration has become increasingly divisive in many Western countries, particularly the United States, polls indicate that most Canadians support it.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Immigrants now make up a record portion of Canada’s population.

item.title: Brazil Confronts a Momentous Bolsonaro vs. Lula Election
item.description: Brazilians head to the polls on Sunday in an election between two political heavyweights that could have global repercussions.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brazil’s far-right president, Jair Bolsonaro, is seeking a second term as he faces off against a leftist opponent and a former president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva.

item.title: Ukraine’s Army Advances Toward Kherson, as Mud Season Arrives
item.description: Fall rains have turned the earth to sludge, slowing advances at least until the winter freeze, in conditions that have hampered military movement for centuries.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier passing the window of a school that was used as a base by Russian forces in Velyka Oleksandrivka, in the Kherson region of Ukraine.

item.title: Saudis Find Sympathetic U.S. Ears at ‘Davos in the Desert’
item.description: A Saudi decision to support a cut in oil output infuriated Washington. But at an investment conference in Riyadh, there was plenty of praise for the kingdom.
item.dc:creator: Kate Kelly and Vivian Nereim
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
Abdulaziz bin Salman, Prince of Saudi Arabia
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The conference has become a magnet for business leaders, drawing more than 5,000 attendees this year alone.

item.title: Russia’s Defense Minister Says Draft Is Complete, and No More Are Planned
item.description: Announced by Mr. Putin in September, the draft sent shock waves across Russia.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Kirill Braga/Reuters
item.media:description: Russian reservists training at a shooting range in the Volgograd region, Russia, last week.

item.title: Scarred by War, Ukraine’s Children Face Years of Trauma
item.description: For countless Ukrainian children, the war has brought long-term physical and psychological injuries. Those who have suffered serious physical harm or the loss of a parent now face a challenging path forward.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Brendan Hoffman
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Maryna Ponomariova, 6, whose left leg had to be amputated below the knee after a devastating attack on her home in Kherson, is now learning to walk again with the help of Nazar Borozniuk at Ohmadyt Children’s Hospital in Kviv, Ukraine, earlier this month.

item.title: Italy’s Hard Right Feels Vindicated by Giorgia Meloni’s Ascent
item.description: Long marginalized politically and ostracized socially, the new prime minister’s supporters sense a chance to give a final blow to the stigma and shame of their association with Fascism.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo and Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of Giorgia Meloni at her final campaign rally in Rome before the election in September.

item.title: With the close of his Twitter deal, Elon Musk’s geopolitical influence is set to grow.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz, Adam Satariano and Chang Che
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Starlink system in use in the Kharkiv region of Ukraine. The system, which can beam internet service to conflict zones and geopolitical hot spots, has become an essential tool of the Ukrainian army.

item.title: Here’s how some Western powers reacted to Putin’s speech.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: A Beginner’s Guide to the U.S. Midterm Elections
item.description: What’s at stake, and how does it work? Let’s start with the basics.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: State races could have a huge effect on issues like abortion rights and voting.

item.title: Ukraine accuses Russia of violating international law by placing Ukrainian children in Russian families.
item.description: The transfer of Ukrainian children from occupied territories to Russia and their adoption by Russian families is a potential war crime.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Evgeniy Maloletka/Associated Press
item.media:description: Smoke rising after shelling in March in Mariupol, Ukraine.

item.title: Xi Jinping vs. the People
item.description: How Chinese citizens are responding to Xi’s lengthened rule.
item.dc:creator: Li Yuan
item.media:credit: Noel Celis/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Effort to Set Vote to Form Northern Ireland Government Hits a Snag
item.description: Britain’s Northern Ireland secretary had been expected to announce on Friday that a new election would be held in December. But a British official failed to set a day for the vote.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Jeff J Mitchell/Getty Images
item.media:description: A polling station in May in Belfast, Northern Ireland. Sinn Fein’s victory that month was a watershed in the country’s politics.

item.title: In Brazil’s Elections, Many Bolsonaro Supporters Expect Fraud
item.description: President Jair Bolsonaro has attacked Brazil’s electronic voting system. Now, ahead of Sunday’s elections, many of his supporters believe there will be fraud.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Maria Magdalena Arrellaga for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mr. Bolsonaro’s supporters focus their attention on a series of anecdotal apparent abnormalities in the voting process and results, as well as many conspiracy theories.

item.title: Yu-Gi-Oh! Creator Kazuki Takahashi Died Trying to Save Others
item.description: Kazuki Takahashi, creator of the internationally famous Yu-Gi-Oh! manga, was found dead in July. At the time, officials did not disclose the circumstances.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and Hisako Ueno
item.media:credit: Peter Endig/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Kazuki Takahashi at the Leipzig Book Fair in Leipzig, Germany, in 2005.

item.title: Ksenia Sobchak, a Kremlin Critic, Leaves Russia
item.description: Ksenia Sobchak entered Lithuania this week.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Yuri Kadobnov
item.media:description: Ksenia Sobchak with President Vladimir V. Putin at the Kremlin in 2018, a day after he won the presidential election, in which she had also been a candidate.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Devin Oktar Yalkin for The New York Times
item.media:description: With more than 3,000 turbines, the Tehachapi Pass wind farms around Mojave, Calif., are some of the largest wind-energy generators in the state.

item.title: For Rishi Sunak, Family Wealth From Outsourcing Adds to a Secretive Fortune
item.description: Britain’s new prime minister married into an $800 million stake in Infosys, a company that does not fit neatly into his party’s views on immigration.
item.dc:creator: Jane Bradley
item.media:credit: Mark Cuthbert/UK Press, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Mr. Sunak and his wife, Akshata Murty, during a reception to celebrate the British Asian Trust at the British Museum in February.

item.title: Putin Says Russia Is Battling ‘Strange’ Western Elites
item.description: Ahead of U.S. elections, the Russian leader sounded like some right-wing Westerners, saying his fight is not with those in the West who hold “traditional values.”
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski

item.title: OSCE Election Observers Warn of Republican Election Deniers
item.description: Attempts by candidates to discredit the integrity of the vote have “snowballed enormously” since the 2020 election, the head of the observation mission said.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.category: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
item.media:credit: Jodi Hilton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Voting in the Massachusetts primary last month. A report by the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe highlighted a number of concerns for the U.S. midterm elections.

item.title: G.O.P. Senator’s Report on Covid Origins Suggests Lab Leak, but Offers Little New Evidence
item.description: The report, signed by Senator Richard Burr, foreshadows a new wave of political wrangling over Covid’s origins if Republicans gain control of the House or Senate.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller and Carl Zimmer
item.media:credit: Thomas Peter/Reuters
item.media:description: Security personnel outside the Wuhan Institute of Virology during a visit by the W.H.O. to investigate the origins of the coronavirus, in Wuhan, China, in February 2021.

item.title: Memorials for 2 Young Women Killed in Iran Galvanize Protests
item.description: For a second day in a row, tens of thousands of demonstrators protested across Iran against the country’s authoritarian clerical rule. The government response on Thursday was again deadly.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:credit: via Reuters
item.media:description: A video distributed on social media on Wednesday showing people marching toward the cemetery where Mahsa Amini, who died after being detained by Iran’s morality police, is buried.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: The U.S. Economy Grew, Slowly
item.description: Plus the war in Ukraine may boost clean energy and investigations into Chinese outposts overseas.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: By The New York Times
item.media:description: Note: Quarterly changes in gross domestic product, adjusted for inflation. Source: Bureau of Economic Analysis

item.title: Iraqi Parliament Approves New Government After Yearlong Delay
item.description: The installation of a new prime minister and cabinet ends a long-running political deadlock, but perpetuates a system plagued by corruption and dysfunction.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
